title: 114_hr5658
content: The "Tested Ability to Leverage Exceptional National Talent Act of 2016" or the "TALENT Act of 2016" establishes the Presidential Innovation Fellows Program under Chapter 31 of title 5, United States Code. The Presidential Innovation Fellows Program aims to attract skilled individuals to work on national challenges, partnering with government leaders to create solutions that benefit the American people. The Administrator of General Services oversees the Program, enabling proven individuals to serve time-limited appointments in the Executive branch. The Presidential Innovation Fellows Program, administered by the Director appointed by the Administrator of General Services Administration, aims to address significant national challenges by appointing skilled individuals to work on projects aligned with the President's goals. The Program facilitates the placement of fellows in Executive agencies to utilize innovative techniques and technology for positive effects. The Director prescribes the application process for fellows to participate in projects. The Director of the Presidential Innovation Fellows Program establishes processes for applications and nominations, sets Governmentwide caps on the number of fellows, and defines salary ranges and benefits. Procedures for selection, appointment, and assignment of fellows are prescribed, with consultation with Executive agency heads before selection. The Director consults with Executive agency heads to select fellows for short-term appointments of 6 months to 2 years. Agencies work with the Director to maximize program benefits by identifying impactful initiatives. The Presidential Innovation Fellows Program involves identifying impactful initiatives that benefit from fellows' involvement. An advisory board advises on program priorities and standards, assisting in project placements for fellows. The board does not participate in the selection process. The advisory board for the Presidential Innovation Fellows Program includes the Chair, Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, Director of the Office of Personnel Management, Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government, Chief Technology Officer, and other designated individuals. The board may consult with industry, academia, or nonprofits to enhance the program's effectiveness in addressing national challenges. The advisory board for the Presidential Innovation Fellows Program includes key government officials and may consult with external entities to address national challenges. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 31 of title 5, United States Code. The Presidential Innovation Fellows Program, established under Executive Order 13704, is described in this section. No additional funds are authorized for this program. The House of Representatives passed this Act on July 12, 2016.
